questions.question: Isolation is a problem only when multiple users are accessing the same data concurrently.
A schedule can be considered serial if its transactions occur consecutively, one after another.
In a conflict pair, both operations must belong to the same transaction.
Two operations are in conflict only if they operate on different data items.
An operation that writes a data item can be involved in a conflict with another operation that reads the same item.
Two operations that are both writes on the same data item always conflict.
A read–read pair on the same data item from different transactions is a conflicting operation pair.
If one transaction reads a data item and another writes to it, the order of those operations must be preserved for conflict serializability.
Two schedules are conflict equivalent if they have exactly the same set of operations in any order.
A schedule is conflict serializable if it can be transformed into some serial schedule by swapping non‑conflicting operations.
View serializability is a stricter requirement than conflict serializability.
If a transaction aborts, all other transactions that used its results must also be rolled back for recoverability.
Cascade updates use ON DELETE CASCADE and ON UPDATE CASCADE only in foreign key definitions.
A deadlock is a state where two or more transactions hold locks but never release them, causing a halt.
Deadlock avoidance always requires aborting one of the transactions to resolve the conflict.
The wait‑for graph is used to detect deadlocks in small databases.
A schedule that causes cascading rollbacks is called a cascading abort schedule.
View equivalent schedules must have the same initial read order for all data items.
